title: Dylife Waterfall Walk Route

images.title: The Star Inn, Dylife by David Purchase, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Star Inn, Dylife

images.title: David Neal / Former mine workings at Dylife
images.caption: Former mine workings at Dylife. This stream (Afon Twymyn) skirts the very northern edge of this square.

images.title: The lip of Ffrwd Fawr waterfall by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The lip of Ffrwd Fawr waterfall

images.title: Part of the gorge on the Afon Twymyn below Dylife by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Part of the gorge on the Afon Twymyn below Dylife. Before the last Ice age, the River Twymyn did not flow through the valley. When the valley was filled by a glacier, the ice ground out a U-shaped glaciated valley. When the glacier that filled the valley melted the Twymyn started to run down the wide channel left behind and the fast flowing river further eroded the valley, cutting the V-shaped gorge as seen today.

images.title: Information board at the Dylife Gorge viewpoint car park by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Information board at the Dylife Gorge viewpoint car park

images.title: Trevor Harris / Footpath to Pennant-uchaf
images.caption: Footpath to Pennant-uchaf. Footpath to Pennant-uchaf The narrow stony path drops steeply down through gorse and heather towards the cottages at Pennant-uchaf and Afon Twymyn.

images.title: Chris Andrews / Ffrwd Fawr
images.caption: Ffrwyd Fawr Waterfall. The River Twymyn flows from the 40-metre-high (130 ft) Ffrwd Fawr Waterfall at the head of the Pennant Valley

description: This circular walk visits the wonderful Ffrwd Fawr waterfall from the village of Dylife in Powys. On the way you will also pass the old mine workings, revealing the industrial history of the area. The route then passes the Dylife Look out point where there are some spectacular views over the gorge. This area also has a car park and an information board. On the eastern section you will climb to an excellent spot with great views down to the falls. The epic Glyndwr's Way passes just to the south. You could pick up this waymarked trail to further explore the area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To the south there's the expansive Llyn Clywedog where there are miles of great waterside cycling and walking trails. Just to the west there's the Glaslyn Nature Reserve where you can enjoy a circular walk around a tranquil lake and look out for a variety of interesting flora and fauna.

display_address: Dylife, Llanbrynmair, Powys, Cymru / Wales, SY19 7BW, United Kingdom
